peopleAlsoAsk.question: Are glass or metal washboards older?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: A "fluted" metal washboard was patented in the United States by Stephen Rust in 1833. Zinc washboards were manufactured in the United States from the middle of the 19th century. In the late 20th century and early 21st century, ridges of galvanized steel are most common, but some modern boards are made of glass.
peopleAlsoAsk.title: Washboard (laundry) - Wikipedia

peopleAlsoAsk.question: When did people stop using washboards?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: We are not exactly sure when washboards were first created and used, but in this country they were used regularly into the 1950s, at which point they were replaced entirely by washing machines.
peopleAlsoAsk.title: History of washing - Muzeum Svitavy

peopleAlsoAsk.question: Do people still use washboards?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: “Lots of people still use them for stain removal,” reports James Martin, a company co-owner who does double duty as manager of the factory. “Say you've got egg on your shirt. You just get some laundry soap, wet the stain, and rub it on your washboard for 5 or 10 seconds, just like Grandma used to do.
peopleAlsoAsk.title: Where Washboards Are Corrugated and Celebrated

peopleAlsoAsk.question: What is the point of a washboard?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: The washboard features two grooves on each side to accommodate various sink edges, ensuring stability during washing. It also comes with a soap storage area and a convenient handle for hanging or handheld use. Its smooth, burr-free surface protects garments from damage during washing.
